newsitem.title: USA: FAA orders inspection of European helicopters.
newsitem.headline: FAA orders inspection of European helicopters.

text.p: The U.S. Federal Aviation Administration Friday ordered the grounding and inspection of some models of a European-made helicopter after an April 15 crash in New York that killed one man and injured three.

"The investigation of the accident revealed that the tail boom -- which holds the stabilizing rotor -- broke off," the FAA said in a statement. "It was determined the failure was caused by fatigue cracking."
The agency ordered all U.S. operators of specific Eurocopter Deutschland GmbH (ECD) helicopters to inspect the tail booms prior to further flight.
Eurocopter is 70 percent owned by France's state group Aerospatiale and 30 percent owned by Germany's Daimler-Benz Aerospace.
The directive involved 132 helicopters and required inspection of the tail boom of models MBB-BK117 A-1, A-3, A-4, B-1, B-2 and C-1, for cracks, loose rivets, or other anomalies, the statement said.
"If no cracks are found, the helicopter may be flown, but must be re-inspected every 100 hours of service," the FAA said.
If cracks were found, the helicopter must be grounded and may not fly again until the manufacturer has developed a repair procedure to submit to the FAA for approval, according to the agency's order.
The FAA said the directive was prompted by the crash of an ECD model MBB-BK117 series helicopter into New York's East River.
The aircraft belonged to Colgate-Palmolive Co., the household products giant, and carried a pilot, co-pilot and two passengers. The company's chief technical officer died in the crash.
